section.title: Setting Up a SystemBuilder Production Environment
section.para: The traditional system development life cycle (SDLC) includes several stages, such as requirements analysis, system architecture, design and implementation, testing, deployment and maintenance. The stages with which SystemBuilder is an integral part are implementation, testing, deployment and maintenance. Within the SystemBuilder realm, implementation and testing include development, often with a sandbox server for creating and testing the client systems. A second phase of testing includes staging, which allows you to test the pre-release the distribution before releasing it for production. This simulated environment includes completing the build and deployment processes plus using the distribution as intended for a period of time. The final component, production, enables deployment of the distribution to a client system. Maintenance is an on-going process that could involve all of these stages.

SystemBuilder's ability to combine an OS with any number of applications makes it at once powerful and complicated. The advantage of using a repetitive isolated process described above is that you can develop, test and fine-tune your system distribution before gradually testing its interactions with the outside world and, finally, releasing it for others to use. Within the Linux release environment, applications and OS are updated and upgraded at a variety of rates. This process gives you optimum control over what patches, updates, enhancements and upgrades you choose to maintain and release to your customers.

section.title: The SDLC Process Step-by-Step
section.para: SystemBuilder's logical network diagram, below, and subsequent description of steps covers the process in more detail.

To set up an environment with SystemBuilder, you would need a Development, or sandbox, system (D); a Version Control system (V); a Staging system (S); and a Production system (P). Development and Staging would contain identical installations of a SystemBuilder version on identical hardware with the same OS. The Production system, which would serve as your download server, should have a Linux-based OS and be web-accessible for client systems to be able to access it to retrieve distribution contents. The Version system should have a Linux-based OS with a compatible version control system.

One variable worth noting is that the hostname for Staging and Production systems is identical; this compatibility will aid in Step 7, migrating the built distribution to a production download server. The hostnames for Development and Version Control are different from the others.

Another point about the diagram is that the Production system is outside your internal firewall, in the DMZ. If client systems will access the Production system from the Internet, it should be in the DMZ.

listitem.para: During this phase you will work with the Development system (D). In addition to creating the samber-server.xml definition file, you will also create any configuration files necessary for the system to run properly, such as smb.conf. Essentially, you will complete the process described in "Defining Your System" in Part I, Chapter 2.

varlistentry.term: Step 2: Build Your System Distribution and Deploy and Test it on a Sandbox Client

listitem.para: This step entails building and deploying your distribution as in Part I, Chapter 2, and testing the functionality of your distribution to make sure it does what it is supposed to do. Steps 1 and 2 are iterative during the alpha release phase, with you incorporating changes to the system definition or configuration files and testing them until you are satisfied with the end result, i.e. a system distribution that deploys correctly and the resulting client functionality performs as expected.

varlistentry.term: Step 3: Check-in Your Definition Files to Version Control

listitem.para: Once you are satisfied with the results in Step 2, you will set up your Version Control repository (V) and check in system definition and configuration files to create the beta release. From this point forward, if you need to adjust your distribution in any way, you can check out and alter these files only using the Development system.

varlistentry.term: Step 4: Check-out Your Distribution Files to Staging

listitem.para: Now that your beta release is available, you are ready to complete the pre-release build/deploy/test process. Check out the repository with the definition and configuration files from Version Control. If you made several revisions to the files, check out the version you want to deploy.

varlistentry.term: Step 5: Build Your Distribution and Deploy and Test it on a Staging Client

listitem.para: Using SystemBuilder on the Staging system (S), you build the distribution with the systembuilder command, i.e. systembuilder samber-server.xml. SystemBuilder will create your distribution in the same location as in Step 2. After deploying the distribution to a Staging Client, test this beta version. If the results are unsatisfactory, go back to Development, check out the appropriate files from Version Control and make the appropriate changes, then check in. Use the iterative process in Steps 1-5 until you are satisfied with the results. Run the SystemBuilder test at least twice to confirm cache performance.

varlistentry.term: Step 6: Check-in Your Distribution Definition and Configuration to Version Control

listitem.para: Once you have successfully built, deployed and tested your distribution on the Staging Client, you can check in the system definition and configuration files to Version Control. Including the system definition itself in this system has one distinct advantage. By utilizing the control part of the system, you have a record of who make changes to the defintion and when. It also audits what changed in each version.

varlistentry.term: Step 7: Migrate Your System Distribution to Production for Release

listitem.para: Now you are ready to migrate the RPMs and distribution images that are a result of the successful build in Step 5 and that were checked into the Version Control system. You will not rerun SystemBuilder on the Production system (P). Rather, you migrate the distribution to Production and release them for download access. This practice also ensures a controlled release into Production, which improves the lock-down and control process for releasing system distribution such as DNS or SMTP servers to the sanitized DMZ environment.

varlistentry.term: Step 8: Deploy Your Distribution to Production Clients

listitem.para: As in Part I, Chapter 2, the "Deploying Clients" section, you will create the boot media from the Staging system and use it to install client systems. In turn, the clients will download the system RPMs from the Production system.

section.para: Once you have deployed the distribution to production clients, you may discover changes that need to be made. OS or applications can have updates, incorporating bug fixes or other planned changes. They can have upgrades or full version releases with new features. Or you may want to add or remove applications or change configuration settings. Depending upon the change needed, the process will differ. Part III will discuss the differences and methods of implementation.
